sections.subtitle: Tools and techniques for evaluating your portfolio performance

sections.title: What You'll Learn
items: How to calculate personal rates of return

sections.title: Essential Performance Metrics
sections.content: Track total return (income + capital appreciation), time-weighted return (eliminates timing effects), and money-weighted return (includes your contribution timing). Compare against appropriate benchmarks like the S&P 500 for stocks or Barclays Aggregate for bonds.

points.title: Total Return
points.description: Income (dividends/interest) plus price appreciation, expressed as a percentage.

points.title: Benchmark Comparison
points.description: Compare your returns to relevant market indices to assess relative performance.

points.title: Risk-Adjusted Returns
points.description: Sharpe ratio and Sortino ratio measure return per unit of risk taken.

sections.title: Consistency Over Time
sections.content: Focus on long-term performance rather than short-term results. Investment success is measured in years and decades, not months or quarters.

sections.title: Personal Performance Tracking
sections.content: Use investment tracking tools or spreadsheets to monitor your portfolio's performance. Track contributions and withdrawals separately from investment returns. Calculate your personal rate of return to understand how your timing affects results.

sections.title: Analyze Your Portfolio Performance
steps: Set up a system to track your investment returns and contributions
Compare your performance to appropriate benchmarks quarterly
Calculate your risk-adjusted returns using online calculators
Use performance analysis to identify areas for improvement

sections.title: Don't Chase Past Performance
sections.content: Past performance doesn't guarantee future results. Use performance analysis to learn about your investment behavior and process, not to chase hot investments.
